day1.title: Day 1: Logic Basics and Language

courseGoals.title: Course Objectives
courseGoals.description: This course aims to introduce the basic concepts of logic, helping students understand the importance of logic in daily life and academic research. By learning to identify statements and understand the structure of arguments, students will develop preliminary logical thinking skills.
courseGoals.afterCompletion: After completing this course, students will be able to:
goals: Understand the definition and subject of logic
Distinguish between statements and non-statements
Identify premises and conclusions in arguments
Understand different functions of language

whatIsLogic.title: What is Logic
whatIsLogic.description: Logic is the study of valid inference. It focuses on the form and structure of arguments, rather than their content. Logic helps us distinguish between good and bad arguments, thereby making more reasonable judgments and decisions.
questions: How to evaluate the quality of arguments?
How to avoid common logical fallacies?
whatIsLogic.applications: Logic has important applications in many fields, including mathematics, philosophy, law, scientific research, and decision-making in daily life.

statements.title: Statements and Non-statements
statements.description: In logic, we first need to distinguish between statements and non-statements.
statements.statementsDescription: Statements are sentences that can be judged as true or false. They express a complete thought and make an assertion about something.
statementsExamplesList: Taipei is the capital of Taiwan.
The Earth revolves around the Sun.
statements.nonStatementsDescription: Non-statements are sentences that cannot be judged as true or false. They may be questions, commands, exclamations, or expressions of wishes.
nonStatementsExamplesList: Happy birthday to you. (Expression of wish)
statements.importance: In logic, we mainly focus on statements, because only statements can be components of arguments.

arguments.title: Argument Structure
arguments.description: An argument consists of a set of statements, some of which (premises) are used to support another statement (conclusion).
arguments.premiseDescription: Premises are statements used to support the conclusion. They provide reasons for accepting the conclusion.
arguments.conclusionDescription: The conclusion is the statement that the argument attempts to prove or support.
arguments.example:
All humans are mortal. (Premise)
Socrates is human. (Premise)
Therefore, Socrates is mortal. (Conclusion)

arguments.premiseIndicatorsDescription: Similarly, there are words typically used to introduce premises, known as premise indicators. Common premise indicators include:

languageFunctions.title: Language Functions
languageFunctions.description: Language has multiple functions, understanding these functions helps us better analyze and use language.
languageFunctions.informativeDescription: The informative function of language is used to convey facts and information. This is the function that logic is most concerned with, as it directly relates to truth-value judgments.
languageFunctions.informativeExamples: For example: "Today is Monday." "The chemical formula for water is H2O."
languageFunctions.directiveDescription: The directive function of language is used to issue commands or requests, guiding others to act.
languageFunctions.directiveExamples: For example: "Please close the door." "Do not touch the hot surface."
languageFunctions.expressiveDescription: The expressive function of language is used to express emotions, attitudes, and feelings.
languageFunctions.expressiveExamples: For example: "I'm happy to see you!" "This is disappointing."
languageFunctions.ceremonialDescription: The ceremonial function of language is used for social etiquette and ceremonial occasions.
languageFunctions.ceremonialExamples: For example: "Good morning." "Happy birthday." "Nice to meet you."
languageFunctions.logicFocus: In logic, we mainly focus on the informative function of language, as only this function directly relates to truth-value judgments.

summary.title: Course Summary
points: Logic is the study of valid inference
Statements can be judged as true or false, while non-statements cannot
Arguments consist of premises and conclusions, with premises supporting the conclusion
Conclusion indicators and premise indicators help us identify the structure of arguments
Language has multiple functions, including informative, directive, expressive, and ceremonial functions
summary.foundation: These basic concepts lay the foundation for our subsequent study of more complex logical concepts.

day2.title: Day 2: Arguments and Fallacies
day2.description: Understand the distinction between valid and invalid arguments, recognize the characteristics of deductive and inductive reasoning, and learn to identify common logical fallacies.

deductiveReasoning.fromGeneralToSpecific: From general to specific: Reasoning from general principles to specific cases
deductiveReasoning.highCertainty: High certainty of conclusion: If the premises are true, the conclusion must be true
deductiveReasoning.noNewInfo: No new information: Only reveals information already implicit in the premises

inductiveReasoning.fromSpecificToGeneral: From specific to general: Reasoning from specific cases to general principles
inductiveReasoning.lowerCertainty: Lower certainty of conclusion: Even if the premises are true, the conclusion may not be true
inductiveReasoning.addsNewInfo: Adds new information: Goes beyond the information contained in the premises

steps.identifyProblem: Identify the problem: Clearly define the problem you want to solve or the argument you want to evaluate
steps.gatherInfo: Gather information: Find relevant facts, data, and perspectives
steps.evaluateEvidence: Evaluate evidence: Check the reliability and relevance of the evidence
steps.considerAlternatives: Consider alternative explanations: Think about other possible explanations or viewpoints
steps.formConclusion: Form a conclusion: Draw a conclusion based on evidence and reasoning

attitudes.openness: Openness: Willingness to consider different perspectives and possibilities
attitudes.curiosity: Curiosity: Maintaining curiosity about the nature and causes of things
attitudes.skepticism: Skepticism: Not easily accepting unverified claims
attitudes.humility: Humility: Acknowledging the limitations of one's knowledge and understanding
attitudes.systematicity: Systematicity: Thinking about problems in an organized way

options: A. If all premises are true, then the conclusion must be true
B. All premises and the conclusion must be true
C. The conclusion must contain new information
D. There must be at least three premises

q2.text: The definition of a Sound Argument is:
options: A. An argument where all premises are true
B. An argument where the conclusion is true
C. An argument that is both valid and has true premises

q6.text: "Famous actor Xiao Hua says this weight loss pill is effective, so it must be effective." What type of logical fallacy is this?

q7.text: "If we allow students to use phones in class, they will play with their phones all day, not study, and ultimately fail academically." What type of logical fallacy is this?

q9.text: Which of the following is an example of an Invalid Argument?
options: A. All mammals have lungs. Whales are mammals. Therefore, whales have lungs.
B. If it rains, the ground will be wet. The ground is wet. Therefore, it has rained.
C. All metals expand when heated. Copper is a metal. Therefore, copper expands when heated.
D. All humans are mortal. Socrates is human. Therefore, Socrates is mortal.

q10.text: Which of the following is NOT a basic step in Critical Thinking?

reviewPoints: Valid Argument: If all premises are true, then the conclusion must be true
Sound Argument: An argument that is both valid and has true premises
Deductive Reasoning: From general to specific, with high certainty of conclusion
Inductive Reasoning: From specific to general, with lower certainty of conclusion
Common Logical Fallacies: Ad Hominem, Appeal to Authority, Straw Man, Slippery Slope, Appeal to Emotion
Basic steps of Critical Thinking: Identifying problems, gathering information, evaluating evidence, considering alternative explanations, forming conclusions
Attitudes of Critical Thinking: Openness, curiosity, skepticism, humility, systematic approach

slide2.title: What is Logic
content: Logic is the study of valid inference.
It focuses on the form and structure of arguments, rather than their content.
Logic helps us distinguish between good and bad arguments, thereby making more reasonable judgments and decisions.

slide3.title: Core Questions in Logic
questions: How to evaluate the quality of arguments?
How to avoid common logical fallacies?

slide4.title: Statements
content: Statements are sentences that can be judged as true or false.
For example:
Taipei is the capital of Taiwan.
The Earth revolves around the Sun.
All humans are mortal.

slide5.title: Non-statements
content: Non-statements are sentences that cannot be judged as true or false.
For example:
Please close the door. (Command)
How is the weather today? (Question)
What a beautiful scenery! (Exclamation)
Happy birthday to you. (Expression of wish)

slide6.title: Argument Structure
content: An argument consists of a set of statements, some of which (premises) are used to support another statement (conclusion).
Premise: A statement used to support the conclusion
Conclusion: The statement that the argument attempts to prove or support

slide7.title: Example of an Argument
content: All humans are mortal. (Premise)
Socrates is human. (Premise)
Therefore, Socrates is mortal. (Conclusion)

slide8.title: Conclusion Indicators
content: In everyday language, there are certain words typically used to introduce conclusions, known as conclusion indicators.
Common conclusion indicators include:
Therefore
Thus
Hence
Consequently
It follows that

slide9.title: Premise Indicators
content: Similarly, there are words typically used to introduce premises, known as premise indicators.
Common premise indicators include:
Because
Since
Given that
Considering that

slide10.title: Language Functions
content: Language has multiple functions, understanding these functions helps us better analyze and use language.

slide11.title: Informative Function of Language
content: The informative function of language is used to convey facts and information.
This is the function that logic is most concerned with, as it directly relates to truth-value judgments.
For example:
Today is Monday.
The chemical formula for water is H2O.

slide12.title: Other Functions of Language
content: Directive Function: Used to issue commands or requests, guiding others to act.
Expressive Function: Used to express emotions, attitudes, and feelings.
Ceremonial Function: Used for social etiquette and ceremonial occasions.

introduction.title: Course Introduction
introduction.paragraph1: 'Introduction to Logic' is a five-day logic course designed for middle school students, based on Irving M. Copi's classic work 'Introduction to Logic'. Each day's lesson is half an hour, with content progressing from basic to advanced, gradually introducing the basic concepts and applications of logic.
introduction.paragraph2: This course aims to develop students' critical thinking skills and logical reasoning techniques, helping them make more reasonable judgments and decisions in learning and life.

features.title: Course Features
features.item1: Easy-to-understand materials: Teaching materials designed for middle school students' cognitive level, making abstract logical concepts easy to understand.
features.item2: Rich visual aids: Each day's lesson comes with mind maps and visual slides to help students better understand and memorize.
features.item3: Interactive exercises: Targeted exercises after each day's lesson to help students consolidate knowledge.
features.item4: English-Chinese terminology: Complete English-Chinese glossary of logical terminology to help students master professional vocabulary.
features.item5: Real-life examples: Help students understand abstract logical concepts through examples from daily life.

structure.day3: Day 3: Logical Connectives and Compound Statements - Learn logical connectives and their application in constructing compound statements, understand the logical structure of conditionals and biconditionals.
structure.day4: Day 4: Deductive Reasoning and Logical Rules - Understand the basic structure of syllogisms, learn to use basic logical symbols, master basic rules of inference.
structure.day5: Day 5: Inductive Reasoning and Critical Thinking - Understand the characteristics and applications of inductive reasoning, learn the principles of analogical reasoning and causal reasoning, comprehensively apply critical thinking skills.

originalWork.title: About the Original Work
originalWork.paragraph1: This course references Irving M. Copi's 'Introduction to Logic'. Copi is a renowned American logician and philosopher, and his work is a classic textbook in the field of logic, widely used in university logic courses.
originalWork.paragraph2: We have appropriately simplified and adjusted the content of the original work according to the cognitive level and learning needs of middle school students, making it more suitable for middle school students.

learningTips.tip5: Complete the exercises to consolidate what you've learned.
learningTips.tip6: Consult the terminology list to familiarize yourself with professional vocabulary.
learningTips.tip7: Apply what you've learned to daily life to cultivate critical thinking habits.
